awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Development of machine learning technology for matching under a variety of realistic and largescale preference structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project focuses on the development of new technologies for achieving efficient two-sided matching under the constraints of fairness and trustworthiness. Numerous technologies presently exist for two-sided matching of supplies and demands. Those assessments that are fair and trustworthy tend to lack efficiency for commercial applications and lack adequate performance specifications, while those with ideal efficiency are too computationally expensive for large-scale markets. The proposed program explores implementation and commercialization opportunities within the project's initial application focus of small to medium-sized businesses in manufacturing. The proposed technologies have a broad application potential, and can materially reduce the time of finding suitable suppliers and lowering prices. Additionally, the longer-term development of the technology may prove disruptive in markets such as call centers and student tutoring websites. The developed technologies may also improve the supply chain and better allocate scarce resources, e.g., vaccines and medicines, while ensuring social efficiency and fairness in the matching process.

This I-Corps project is based on the premise that the intersection of state-of-the-art machine learning and economic principles leads to disruptive innovation. The project's technologies offer a fundamentally different approach to two-sided matching than those developed in the past six decades. This project pursues a data-driven solution to a dynamic two-sided matching problem. Previous progress on this project has focused on the theoretical development of the mechanism design and experimental verification of algorithms in small-scale markets with hundreds of users. By contrast, this project enables a widely scalable approach for millions of users to be matched in real-time and allowing realistic uncertain preferences.  The approach not only yields maximum efficiency but also guarantees outcomes such as trustworthiness and fairness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop new technologies for achieving the most efficient and real-time matching in two-sided markets of demand and supply. The matching algorithms were designed to have four new features: large-scale matching, efficiency, trustworthiness, and fairness. These algorithms are useful for a variety of realistic and large-scale preference structures, and we view small to medium-sized businesses as our primary commercial target. Our goal was to help these businesses find good suppliers and lower prices more quickly. We also hypothesized that call centers, student tutoring websites, and online dating sites could benefit from our novel matching technology. Additionally, we aimed to improve the supply chain and match scarce equipment, vaccines, and medicines with personnel in real-time during pandemics, while also ensuring social efficiency and fairness in the matching process.

To achieve these goals, we conducted 176 customer interviews with staff members and decision-makers of small and medium-sized businesses and manufacturers from across the United States. We also interviewed 48 hospital employees and government agency employees from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to understand the values of our technology in improving the supply chain during pandemics. Our team also developed a software and product and disseminated them to the community.

Our specific objectives included determining the market segment in small and medium-sized businesses that are ready to adopt our technology in the short term of six months. Through customer interviews, we also wanted to understand the values that our platform could significantly contribute to compared to state-of-the-art solutions. Additionally, we aimed to understand the issues in the supply chain for hospitals during pandemics and how our technology could help.

We are pleased to report that our project was a success. We identified the customer segment of designers with small fashion brands who have intense difficulty in finding manufacturers and can significantly benefit from our technology. Specifically, those brands with less than 250 orders/month can substantially reduce the time for finding manufacturers from 4 weeks to 1 day by using our technology. Brands with more than 250 orders/month can also find significantly cheaper supplies with a quality guarantee by using our technology. On the other hand, manufacturers can benefit substantially from our technology by lifting the requirement of minimum orders and avoiding delayed payments. Moreover, those manufacturers can significantly increase the number of orders by 30% in 6 months through international matching using our technology.

In conclusion, our NSF-funded project successfully developed new technologies for efficient and real-time matching in two-sided markets of demand and supply. We identified key market segments that can benefit from our technology, specifically small fashion brands, and conducted extensive interviews and built MVP. We also disseminated the software and app to the community, including an iOS app "Hilbert Matching", which was launched at App Store. We have also created a website: https://www.hilbertmatching.com/. The results of our project demonstrate the potential for significant impact on the efficiency and fairness of matching processes in various industries.
